author: Kavita Upadhyay
text:
“Don't call us bhasha sahityakars (language scholars), call us sahityakars ,” was the plea poets and writers representing Indian languages, including Malyalam, Gujarati and Assamese, made during the second day of the ZEE Jaipur Literature Festival (JLF) here, on Friday.

Speaking at a session titled “Bhasha: freeing the word,” Malayalam poet K. Satchidanandan said: “The word bhasha has a baggage of representing something which is secondary, and I have a problem with the way the word bhasha [sahitya] is used today. All languages must be named.” Mr. Satchidanandan, who resigned from all committees of the Sahitya Akademi to protest against the killing of writer M.M. Kalburgi and the Akademi’s failure to stand with the writers, said no language must be treated as secondary. “Not treating a language as an important one leads to marginalisation of voices,” he said.

Gujarati p+oet and writer Sitanshu Yashaschandra said: “My plea is not to call us bhasha sahityakars , but to call us sahityakars .”

“There are many Indian languages and each language has a literature. The categorisation of Indian literatures as bhasha sahitya is colonial. I reject it,” Mr. Yashaschandra said.

Mr. Yashaschandra said that the term bhasha was used as a second grade term against English, which was considered an international language of literature.
title: Call us sahityakars, say writers at JLF
